turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I'm sorry if I let you down.

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: You didn't let ME down. Or even Lou. We don't live or die by what you scribble, Fink. You let Ben Geisler down. He liked you. Trusted you. And that's why he's gone. Fired.  That guy had a heart as big as the outdoors, and you fucked him. He tried to convince me to fire you too, but that would be too easy. No, you're under contract and you're gonna stay that way.  Anything you write will be the property of Capitol Pictures. And Capitol Pictures will not produce anything you write. Not until you grow up a little. You ain't no writer, Fink  you're a goddamn write-off.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I tried to show you something beautiful.  Something about all of US 

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Welcome to the Hotel Earle. May I help you, sir?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I'm checking in. Barton Fink.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: F-I-N-K. Fink, Barton. That must be you, huh?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Must be.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Okay then, everything seems to be in order. Everything seems to be in order.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: ...Are you a tranz or a rez?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Excuse me?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Transient or resident?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: I don't know... I mean, I'll be here, uh, indefinitely.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Rez. That'll be twenty-five fifty a week payable in advance. Checkout time is twelve sharp, only you can forget that on account you're a rez. If you need anything, anything at all, you dial zero on your personal in-room telephone and talk to me. My name is Chet.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Well, I'm going to be working here, mostly at night; I'm a writer. Do you have room service?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Kitchen closes at eight but I'm the night clerk. I can always ring out for sandwiches.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: ...Okay

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Okey-dokey, go ahead.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: What 

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Don't you wanna go to your room?!

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: ...Those your only bags?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: The others are being sent.

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: L.A.P.D.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: Jesus! Ain't that a load off! You live in 605?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: Is this multiple choice?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Nine days  Tuesday 

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: ...Yeah, he... he lives next door to me.

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: That's right, Fink, he lives next door to you.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: What did... What did he 

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: Funny. As in, he likes to ventilate people with a shotgun and then cut their heads off.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Charlie... Charlie's back...

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: No kidding, bright boy  we smelt Mundt all over this. Was he the idea man?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Sex?! He's a MAN! We WRESTLED!

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: You're a sick fuck, Fink.

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: Got a couple questions to ask ya.

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: What do you do, Fink?

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: Big fuckin' deal.

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: You want my partner to kiss your ass?

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: Would that be good enough for ya?

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: Yeah, and I'm Buck Rogers.

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: His name is Mundt. Karl Mundt.

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: Also known as Madman Mundt.

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: He's a little funny in the head.

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: Started in Kansas City. Couple of housewives.

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: Couple of days ago we see the same M.O. out in Los Feliz.

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: Doctor. Ear, nose and throat man,.

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: All of which he's now missin'.

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: Well, some of his throat was there.

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: Physician, heal thyself.

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: Good luck with no fuckin' head.

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: Anyway.

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: Hollywood precinct finds another stiff yesterday. Not too far from here. This one's better looking than the doc.

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: Female caucasian, thirty years old. Nice tits. No head. You ever see Mundt with anyone meets that description?

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: But, you know, with the head still on.

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: Yeah, and he's Buck Rogers.

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: No reputable company would hire a guy like that.

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: Ya know, Fink, ordinarily we say anything you might remember could be helpful. But I'll be frank with you: That is not helpful.

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: Ya see how he's not writing it down?

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: Fink. That's a Jewish name, isn't it?

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: ...I thought you said you were a writer.

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: I dunno, Duke. I kinda liked it.

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: Second one of your friends to end up dead.

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: You didn't tell us you knew the dame.

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: Sixth floor too high for you, Fink?

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: Give you nose bleeds?

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: Tell us where the heads are, maybe they'll go easy on you.

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: Only fry you once.

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: He teach you to do it?

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: You two have some sick sex thing?

turns.speaker: DEUTSCH
turns.text: Why's it so goddamn hot out here?

turns.speaker: MASTRIONOTTI
turns.text: ...Fred...

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Mr. Fink hasn't given a preference, Mr.  Lipnik.

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: How's about it, Bart?

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: ...Thanks Lou. Join us. Join us. Talking about the Wallace Beery picture.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Excellent picture.

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: We got a treatment on it yet?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: No, not yet Jack. We just bought the story. Saturday Evening Post.

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: Okay, the hell with the story. Wallace Beery is a wrestler. I wanna know his hopes, his dreams. Naturally, he'll have to get mixed up with a bad element. And a romantic interest. You know the drill.  Romantic interest, or else a young kid. An orphan. What do you think, Lou? Wally a little too old for a romantic interest?  Look at me, a writer in the room and I'm askin' Lou what the goddamn story should be!

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: ...Maybe we should do a treatment.

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: Ah, hell, let Bart take a crack at it.  He'll get into the swing of things or I don't know writers. Let's make it a dame, Bart, keep it simple. We don't gotta tackle the world our first time out. The important thing is we all have that Barton Fink feeling, but since you're Barton Fink I'm assuming you have it in spades.  Seriously Bart, I like you. We're off to a good start. Dammit, if all our writers were like you I wouldn't have to get so goddamn involved. I'd like to see something by the end of the week.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Mr. Lipnik, I 

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: This man creates for a living! He puts food on your table and on mine! THANK him for it!  Thank him, you ungrateful sonofabitch! Thank him or YOU'RE fired!

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: Get down on your knees, you sonofabitch!  Get down on your knees and kiss this man's feet!

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Mr. Lipnik, please 

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Yes, Colonel.

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: Hell, I could take you through it step by step, explain why your story stinks, but I won't insult your intelligence. Well all right, first of all: This is a wrestling picture; the audience wants to see action, drama, wrestling, and plenty of it. They don't wanna see a guy wrestling with his soul  well, all right, a little bit, for the critics  but you make it the carrot that wags the dog. Too much of it and they head for exits and I don't blame 'em. There's plenty of poetry right inside that ring, Fink. Look at "Hell Ten Feet Square".

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: "Blood, Sweat, and Canvas".

turns.speaker: LIPNIK
turns.text: Look at "Blood, Sweat, and Canvas". These are big movies, Fink. About big men, in tights  both physically and mentally. But especially physically. We don't put Wallace Beery in some fruity movie about suffering  I thought we were together on that.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Okay.  I went after him.  I lost my temper.

turns.speaker: AN I.A. MAN
turns.text: Do you have any evidence that he showed your psychiatric file to anyone?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: AN I.A. MAN
turns.text: Where were you tonight?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Home. Watching TV.

turns.speaker: AN I.A. MAN
turns.text: All night?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: AN I.A. MAN
turns.text: Were you drinking?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Yeah, I was drinking.

turns.speaker: AN I.A. MAN
turns.text: When did you start drinking again?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: A couple days ago.

turns.speaker: AN I.A. MAN
turns.text: There's no smoking in this building.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What are you gonna do -- charge me with smoking?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Come on -- I'm going to storm into his office in front of everybody in the afternoon and then that night I'm going to kill him?  I'd have to be really dumb to do that.

turns.speaker: AN I.A. MAN
turns.text: Going after him before gets you off the hook for killing him that's your alibi.

turns.speaker: AN I.A. MAN
turns.text: I want you in Dr. Gardner's office at nine o'clock.  You're out of control, Curran.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Who are you guys gonna sell my file to this time?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: We got a call from Berkeley P.D. There was a killing.  A professor. Icepick.  In his bed.  Multiple stab wounds.  1977.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: She was there, wasn't she?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Take care, you hear?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Did you find out about her parents?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: You're on leave, man.  You're on psycho leave.  I'm talking to a possible whacko here.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You know I'm whacko, Sam, what'd you find?

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: The boat blew.  There was a leak in the gas line.  There were two previous repairs.  There was a five-mil policy on both of 'em.  A real heavy investigation.  Zilch. Goose-egg.  It was an accident.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: I can get my butt kicked for this. You're not supposed to be in here.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: It's not gonna take long, Sam.

turns.speaker: ANDREWS
turns.text: Hey, that's Dr. Gardner, isn't it?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Bring 1976 up.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: How are you, Nick?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I'm fine.  Come on, Beth!  You know I'm fine!  How the hell long do I have to keep doing this?

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: As long as Internal Affairs wants you to, I suppose.  Sit down, Nick.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: It's bullshit.  You know it is.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: I know it is -- but sit down anyway so we can get it over with, okay?

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: So -- how are things?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Things are fine.  I told you. They're fine.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: How is your -- personal life?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: My sex life is fine.  My sex life is pretty shitty actually since I stopped seeing you -- maybe I should think about my Electrolux again.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: How about the booze?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: It's been three months.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: How about the coke?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: No?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: No!  I'm working my tail off.  I'm off the sauce, I'm not even smoking anymore.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: How's not smoking?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: It's fucked -- now will you please tell I.A. that I'm just you average healthy totally fucked-up cop and let me get out of here?

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: You okay?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: You don't look so okay.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: Baby-sitting.  Rookie cop.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What else is new?

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: What was she like?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: Catherine Tramell.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: She said what you said she'd say.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: We were in some of the same classes.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Why didn't you tell me?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I need a cigarette.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: I thought you quit.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: What are you talking about, Nick -- what's wrong with you?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Who's got access to my goddamn file?

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: It's a confidential psychiatric record, it'd be illegal --She backs into a wall.  She looks very scared. He comes very close to her -- puts an arm behind her to the wall.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Don't, Beth.  Don't lie to me.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: It's Internal Affairs, isn't it?

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: No, Nick, please --

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: Nilsen.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I don't owe you anything; you don't owe me anything.  We went to bed -- what was it? -- ten or fifteen times?  It wasn't memorable enough to carry any obligations.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: Sometimes I really hate you.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Yeah?  Well why don't you find some friendly therapist and work some of that hostility out.  But take my advice.  Put a little more life into it than you usually do.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You did it for me.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: Yes.  I care about you.  I did it for you.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: It's the least I could do... considering I got you into this mess with those reports.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: No.  I mean it, thank you.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: How do you know Catherine Tramell saw my reports?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: She knows stuff about me that only you know.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: She must really be something.  From a clinical point of view.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What was she like in school?

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: I hardly knew her.  She gave me the creeps, though.  I don't know why.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Beth.  I didn't mean what I said. About --

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: Yes you did.  I'm a big girl.  I can handle it.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: What is your problem?  I'm trying to help you.  Why won't you let me help you?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I don't need any help.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: Yes you do.  Something's on with you.  You're sleeping with her, aren't you?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What is this interest you've got in her?

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: My interest is in you, not in her. She seduces people, she manipulates --

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I thought you hardly know her.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: I know the type.  I'm a psychologist.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: What do you want, Nick?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Tell me about Catherine.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: She told you, didn't she?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What did she tell me, Beth?

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: I slept with her once in school.  I was just a kid.  I was experimenting.  It was just that one time.  She developed a... fixation... on me.  She styled her hair like mine. She wore the same kind of clothes I did.  It scared me.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: I did dye my hair.  It didn't have anything to do with her.  I was a redhead for a while, too.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Did you know Noah Goldstein?

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: I had him in two classes.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You saw all the reports, Beth!

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: She's really sick you know.  Don't you know what she's doing?  She knows I went to Berkeley.  She knows I knew Noah.  She makes up that story about me.  She's handing you somebody who's obsessed with he her.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: She didn't hand you to me.  She doesn't even know who you are. She told me about Lisa Henderson.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: She knew you'd find out who Lisa Henderson is.  You're a good cop -- what did she do?  Tell you casually and make it seem irrelevant?  Did she tell you in bed, Nick? That's how I'd do it.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Why did you change your name?

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: I got married.  He was on staff at the clinic.  I was down in Salinas.  It didn't... last long.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You should do something about this lock.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: She's evil.  She's brilliant.  Be careful, Nick.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Put your hands up!

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Put your fucking hands up!  Don't move.

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: I got a message on my machine to meet Gus here.  Where is he?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Don't!  I know about your husband.  You still like girls, Beth?

turns.speaker: BETH
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I'm De...

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I know who you are.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: How long were you dating him?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I wasn't dating him.  I was fucking him.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: How long were you having sex with him?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: About a year and a half.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Were you with him last night?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Did you leave the club with him?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Did you go home with him?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: No.  We had a drink at the club. We left together.  I came here. He went home.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Was there anyone with you last night?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: No.  I wasn't in the mood to have sex with anyone last night.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Ms. Tramell, we'd like you to come downtown and answer some questions for us.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Are you arresting me?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: If that's the way you want to play it.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Do you always keep old newspapers around?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Only when they make interesting reading.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Do you have a cigarette?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I don't smoke.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Yes, you do.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I quit.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I thought you were out of cigarettes.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I found some in my purse; would you like one?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I told you -- I quit.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: It won't last.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What's your new book about?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: A detective.  He falls for the wrong woman.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Did I miss something?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I told them you wouldn't want an attorney present.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I told them you wouldn't want to hide.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I have nothing to hide.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: But you said you liked men to use their hands.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: No.  I said I liked Johnny to use his hands.  I don't give any rules, Nick.  I go with the flow.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Writing a book about it gives you an alibi for not killing him.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Yes it does, doesn't it?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You like playing games, don't you?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I've got a degree in psych.  It goes with the turf.  Games are fun.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: How did you feel when he died?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I loved him.  I hurt.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: How did you feel when I told you Johnny Boz had died -- that day at the beach.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I felt somebody had read my book and was playing a game.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: But you didn't hurt --

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Because you didn't love him --

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Even though you were fucking him.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: You still get the pleasure.  Didn't you ever fuck anybody else while you were married, Nick?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I'm tired.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: It's got to be tiring to beat that machine.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: If I were guilty, and if I wanted to beat that machine, it wouldn't be tiring.  It wouldn't be tiring at all.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Because I'm a professional liar. I spend most of my waking hours dwelling on my lies.  For my writing.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I passed.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: You see?  We're both innocent, Nick.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: How do you know all this stuff about me?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: You know all about me.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I don't know anything that isn't police business.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: You know I don't like to wear any underwear, don't you, Nick?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Am I... disturbing you?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: No.  Come in.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Would you like a drink?  I was just going to have one.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: No, thanks.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I'd like to ask you a few more questions.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I'd like to ask you some, too.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You tell me.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I don't know.  But you do.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: It was an accident.  They got in the line of fire.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Four shootings in five years.  All accidents.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: They were drug buys.  I was a vice cop.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Tell me about Professor Goldstein.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: There's a name from the past.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: You want a name from the present? How about Hazel Dobkins?
